head.title: In Situ Self-Formed Nanosheet MoS3/Reduced Graphene Oxide Material Showing Superior Performance as a Lithium-Ion Battery Cathode | ACS Nano

meta.content: In Situ Self-Formed Nanosheet MoS3/Reduced Graphene Oxide Material Showing Superior Performance as a Lithium-Ion Battery Cathode

Although lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries have 5–10 times higher theoretical capacity (1675 mAh g–1) than present commercial lithium-ion batteries, Li–S batteries show a rapid and continuous capacity fading due to the polysulfide dissolution in common electrolytes. Here, we propose the use of a sulfur-based cathode material, amorphous MoS3 and reduced graphene oxide (r-GO) composite, which can be substituted for the pure sulfur-based cathodes. In order to enhance kinetics and stability of the electrodes, we intentionally pulverize the microsized MoS3 sheet into nanosheets and form an ultrathin nano-SEI on the surface using in situ electrochemical methods. Then, the pulverized nanosheets are securely anchored by the oxygen functional group of r-GO. As a result, the electrochemically treated MoS3/r-GO electrode shows superior performance that surpasses pure sulfur-based electrodes; it exhibits a capacity of about 900 mAh g–1 at a rate of 5C for 2500 cycles without capacity fading. Moreover, a full-cell battery employing the MoS3/r-GO cathode with a silicon–carbon composite anode displays a 3–5 times higher energy density (1725 Wh kg–1/7100 Wh L–1) than present LIBs.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
Although lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries have 5–10 times higher theoretical capacity (1675 mAh g
–1
) than present commercial lithium-ion batteries, Li–S batteries show a rapid and continuous capacity fading due to the polysulfide dissolution in common electrolytes. Here, we propose the use of a sulfur-based cathode material, amorphous MoS
3
and reduced graphene oxide (r-GO) composite, which can be substituted for the pure sulfur-based cathodes. In order to enhance kinetics and stability of the electrodes, we intentionally pulverize the microsized MoS
3
sheet into nanosheets and form an ultrathin nano-SEI on the surface using
in situ
electrochemical methods. Then, the pulverized nanosheets are securely anchored by the oxygen functional group of r-GO. As a result, the electrochemically treated MoS
3
/r-GO electrode shows superior performance that surpasses pure sulfur-based electrodes; it exhibits a capacity of about 900 mAh g
–1
at a rate of 5C for 2500 cycles without capacity fading. Moreover, a full-cell battery employing the MoS
3
/r-GO cathode with a silicon–carbon composite anode displays a 3–5 times higher energy density (1725 Wh kg
–1
/7100 Wh L
–1
) than present LIBs.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

div.div:
Among the various energy storage systems used for electrical vehicles (EVs) and grid-scale facilities, rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are currently the most dominant due to their higher energy density, higher energy efficiency, longer lifetime, and higher operating voltage.
(1,2)
Most LIBs use a graphite anode and lithium metal oxide cathode. However, present LIBs are still considered to be too large and too heavy.
(3)
Their energy density chiefly depends on the capacity of the cathode material.
(4,5)
Accordingly, an alternative cathode material with a higher energy density is needed. Sulfur (S) has been identified as a promising cathode material due to it having about 5 times higher energy density (∼2600 Wh kg
–1
) as well as about 30 times lower cost than commercial cathode materials.
(6−10)
Despite the great possibilities, such cathodes face many challenges including low electrical conductivity, volume expansion of 80%, and substantial capacity fading in initial cycles. In particular, high-ordered polysulfides (Li
2
S
x
, 8 ≥
x
≥ 4) formed as intermediate compounds during the electrochemical lithiation reaction are dissolved into the common liquid electrolyte and transfer back and forth between cathode and anode based on concentration gradients (shuttle effect) and form an insulator layer on the electrode surface.
(6−10)
Eventually, electrons and ions are blocked by the insulator film, resulting in rapid capacity fading.
(11,12)
There have been many attempts to mitigate the dissolution of polysulfide:
(10,13)
(i) encapsulating S into porous carbon,
(12)
(ii) coating with a conductive polymer and carbon material,
(14)
and (iii) blending other materials into the electrode composition.
(15)
However, none of the strategies is satisfactory in terms of long-term stability (>1000 cycles), which means they all are not overcoming the impediments for practical use.

Herein, we propose the use of metal sulfides as a sulfur-based cathode material. In particular, metal sulfide, such as molybdenum sulfide (MoS
x
,
x
> 2) that we introduce here, can solve the dissolution of active material by directly forming low-ordered polysulfides (Li
2
S
x
, 4 >
x
≥ 1), without the formation of soluble intermediate products in Li–S batteries.
(16)
Molybdenum disulfide (MoS
2
) has been considered as an anode material.
(17)
Its two-dimensional layered structure with van der Waals interaction between layers enables facile insertion and extraction of lithium ions between the interlayers. In addition, the theoretical capacity of MoS
2
induced by intercalation and conversion reactions is roughly 2 times higher (670 mAh g
–1
) than that of graphite (372 mAh g
–1
). MoS
2
is converted into metallic Mo and Li
2
S through the lithiation reaction; then Mo and S are partially recombined by the delithiation reaction.
(17)
During the lithiation and delithiation reactions in MoS
2
, it is notable that the reversible Li–S reaction between Li
2
S and S occurs at a potential of over 2.2 V
Li+/Li
. Herein, we hypothesize that the operating voltage, with increasing S content in the molybdenum sulfide compound, will be extended to near 2 V
Li+/Li
, as found for the S cathode.
(17−20)
Hence, molybdenum sulfides with a higher content of S (MoS
x
,
x
> 2) than MoS
2
will show potential for utilization as the LIB cathode. In this proof of concept study, we choose molybdenum trisulfide (MoS
3
) as an active material. In order to improve the electrical conductivity and securely anchor the MoS
3
within the electrode, it is composited with reduced graphene oxide (r-GO), and then the final formula we design is MoS
3
/r-GO.

On the other hand, the nanosized material shows relatively good kinetic performance due to a decreased lithium-ion diffusion path; moreover, such a material alleviates the volume change produced during lithiation/delithiation due to a large surface to volume ratio. Therefore, to enhance the performance and stability of the electrode, we intentionally pulverize bulk-sheet MoS
3
into nanoscale by an
in situ
electrochemical method, which is named “
in situ
electrochemical pulverization” in this work. Specifically, we expect that the pulverized nanosheets are securely anchored by the oxygen functional group of r-GO. In addition, to protect the materials from chemical attack, and hence to improve further the stability, we form a nanoscaled solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on the pulverized nanosheets by controlling the potential with a specific electrolyte additive. This process was coined “
in situ
electrochemical SEI formation” in our previous publication.
(21)
Figure
1
a shows the schematic summarizing the
in situ
electrochemical methods to use in this work. Furthermore, since a full-cell for practical use typically shows a much lower electrochemical performance compared to a half-cell,
(22)
a full-cell test is necessary for a realistic study of the feasibility of the material for use as a LIB cathode. Thus, a full-cell battery employing the
in situ
electrochemically treated MoS
3
/r-GO cathode with a high-capacity silicon–carbon electrode is designed and its performance is evaluated.

div.p:
Figure 1.
In situ
electrochemical method and surface morphologies and chemistry of the MoS
x
/r-GO composite. (a) To improve the performance and stability of the electrode, microsized MoS
x
sheets are pulverized into nanosheets using fully repetitive lithiation and delithiation reactions during initial cycling (
in situ
electrochemical pulverization), with a nano SEI layer formed on the pulverized nanosheets by control of the potential with a specific electrolyte additive (
in situ
electrochemical SEI formation). (b) Scanning electron microscope (SEM) surface image and (c) high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) bright field images for MoS
x
/r-GO (inset: ring pattern by selected area electron diffraction, scale bar 10 1/nm). (d) STEM/atomic mapping of MoS
x
/r-GO for molybdenum (Mo), sulfur (S), oxygen (O), and carbon (C). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) surface analysis for (e) Mo 3d and (f) S 2p of MoS
x
/r-GO and MoS
x
. The molybdenum–oxygen and sulfur–oxygen bondings are detected in 235.8 and 169.4 eV. Scale bars: 3 μm (a), 1 μm (b), and 2 μm (c).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In this study, the molybdenum sulfide with a higher content of S (MoS
x
,
x
> 2), which would have more contribution of sulfur in the voltage range (near 2 V
Li+/Li
), was prepared to substitute for the pure sulfur-based cathodes. Moreover, in order to facilitate insertion and extraction of lithium ions
via
an increase in surface area as well as to anchor the pulverized material during the
in situ
electrochemical method, we prepared a two-dimensional form of MoS
x
and r-GO composite using oxygen functional groups of GO.

Figure
1
b–f show the surface morphologies and surface chemistry of the as-prepared MoS
x
/r-GO electrode. According to the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images (
Figure
1
b and c), MoS
x
/r-GO shows a layered morphology with a diameter above 1 μm. Elemental mapping images (
Figure
1
d) indicate that Mo and S are uniformly dispersed onto the large r-GO sheets. Furthermore, from the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of molybdenum (
Figure
1
e) and sulfur (
Figure
1
f) for MoS
3
/r-GO, it is confirmed that Mo and S are well combined with the oxygen functional groups of r-GO. Compared to the pure MoS
3
electrode, the MoS
3
/r-GO composite electrode clearly shows two peaks associated with bonds of Mo–O and S–O (Mo–O: 235.8 eV and S–O
2
: 169.4 eV). According to energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), the molybdenum sulfide compound prepared by a simple chemical method shows the Mo to S ratio of three to one (
Table S1
). Additionally, from the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the as-prepared material (
Figure S1
), it was confirmed that there are two broad peaks near 13.8° and 23.0°, which are associated with MoS
3
(23)
and r-GO,
(24)
respectively, without a crystalline peak. According to the above results, the prepared composite is an amorphous MoS
3
/r-GO composite in the form of microsized sheets.

The first step of
Figure
1
a illustrates the
in situ
electrochemical pulverization to improve the electrochemical performance of the as-prepared MoS
3
/r-GO composite by breaking it into nanoscale particles. As shown in
Figure
2
, repetitive lithiation/delithiation cycling between 0.05 and 3.0 V at 0.5 A g
–1
results in the capacity rapidly decreasing from 2062 mAh g
–1
to 431 mAh g
–1
over the first 24 cycles (step 1). This quick drop is due to the formation of an SEI during the initial formation cycles.
(25)
Over the next 110 cycles, the capacity steadily recovers to 1276 mAh g
–1
(step 2) and holds at that level for the next 400 cycles.
Figure S2
shows the charge/discharge profiles and corresponding d
Q
/d
V
curves. Upon the initial lithiation, four peaks appear at approximately 1.82, 1.63, 1.18, and 0.68 V. Three peaks, at 1.43, 1.89, and 2.30 V, are observed during delithiation. However, the initial peaks of MoS
3
gradually disappear during the subsequent lithiation and different peaks appear, presumably due to phase transformations affecting the cell performance. To elucidate the behavior underlying this observed gradual increase in capacity for the MoS
3
/r-GO during step 2, we studied the morphology of the electrode using high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) for the uncycled state and after 40, 60, 80, 100, and 250 cycles (
Figure
2
b–g) at a magnification of 200 000×. The morphology of the uncycled MoS
3
electrode shows a micrometer-sized layer structure. However, the repetitive electrochemical cycling induces a pulverization of the bulk sheet into nanosheets with a size of 5–7 nm. After 100 cycles, further size reduction is not observed. The average sheet sizes of the 40 cycled, 60 cycled, 80 cycled, 100 cycled, and 250 cycled MoS
3
/r-GO electrodes are 22.8, 14.2, 8.4, 6.0, and 5.8 nm, respectively. As a result, the variation in capacity observed during the initial 110 cycles is ascribed to the pulverization of bulk MoS
3
/r-GO sheet into nanosheets; once further size reduction stopped, the capacity became steady.

div.p:
Figure 2. Electrochemical test data, HR-TEM, and STEM/atomic mapping images for a MoS
3
/r-GO half-cell measured during
in situ
electrochemical pulverization. The electrochemical test for the MoS
3
/r-GO cathode is carried out between 0.05 and 3.0 V at 25 °C. (a) Step change in cycling performance for MoS
3
/r-GO at 0.5 A g
–1
for 380 cycles. (b–g) HR-TEM bright field images of the MoS
3
/r-GO electrode taken before and after 40, 60, 80, 100, and 250 cycles (magnification of about 200 000×). (h) TEM at a magnification of about 100 000× and (i) STEM/atomic mapping at a low magnification of 15 000× (molybdenum (Mo), sulfur (S), oxygen (O), and carbon (C)) images for the MoS
3
/r-GO electrode after 100 cycles. Scale bars: 20 nm (b–g), 100 nm (h), and 250 nm (i).

div.div:
Moreover, TEM and elemental mapping of the electrode after 100 cycles, at low magnifications of 100 000× and 15 000×, respectively, indicate that Mo and S are still uniformly dispersed along the r-GO sheet (
Figure
2
i). This indicates that although bulk MoS
3
sheet is pulverized into nanoscaled sheets, Mo and S combine well with r-GO without dissolution in the electrolyte after 100 cycles. The rate-capability test of
Figure S3
is also evidential. When the test is carried out for varying specific current between 0.25 and 5.0 A g
–1
, the pristine MoS
3
electrode shows a low initial discharge capacity of 1318 mAh g
–1
and fast capacity fading. In contrast, the MoS
3
/r-GO electrode shows a higher rate capability at all the currents compared to pure MoS
3
. This is because r-GO supports the stability and rate capability of MoS
3
. r-GO can not only increase the electrical conductivity of the electrode but also anchor MoS
3
with strong bonds of oxygen functional groups with molybdenum and sulfur (M–O and S–O) (
Figure
1
e and f), as confirmed in
Figure
1
d and
2
i, leading to no separation from the electrode during fully repetitive lithiation and delithiation reactions.

The analysis of the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is consistent with the HR-TEM results discussed above.
Figure S4
shows the Nyquist plots for the MoS
3
/r-GO electrode and the equivalent circuit used to describe the measured data. The data observed in the medium-frequency region (MFR) relate to the charge-transfer resistance (
Table S2
).
(22,26,27)
After 40 cycles, the charge-transfer resistance calculated by fitting the data for MoS
3
/r-GO increases from 256.0 ohm-cm
2
to 889.1 ohm-cm
2
. Following subsequent cycling, however, the charge-transfer resistance gradually decreases to 69.02 ohm-cm
2
. In this study, the microsized structure of MoS
3
is pulverized through electrochemical reaction into a sheet with a size of 5–7 nm. Since the ion-diffusion length through the (002) plane is shortened compared to the length of the pristine microsized sheet, the charge-transfer resistance attributed to ion transfer decreases. Accordingly, we propose that microsized sheets of MoS
3
on r-GO can be pulverized into a nanosized structure by an
in situ
electrochemical method, leading to an increase in diffusivity for lithium ions in the active material and hence a decrease in charge-transfer resistance. The detailed mechanism of pulverization related to electrochemical reactions will be included in the next discussion section.

The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) shows a change in the diffraction pattern measured in the uncycled state compared to that measured after 250 cycles (
Figures
1
c and
S5
). The amorphous pattern for MoS
3
gradually turns into a polycrystalline structure associated with MoS
2
.
(28)
In the XRD pattern measured after 100 cycles (
Figure S6
), the existing broad peaks disappear, while peaks associated with the (002) plane of MoS
2
appear at 15.0°.
(29)
Consequently, amorphous MoS
3
is converted into polycrystalline MoS
2
during fully repetitive lithiation and delithiation reactions.

Figure
3
a–c show the cyclic voltammetry (CV) data measured in the potential range of 0.05–3.0 V. For the case of MoS
2
,
(17,30−32)
the cathode is decomposed into metallic Mo and Li
2
S
via
intercalation and conversion reactions. The acquired CV curves are similar to the d
Q
/d
V
curves of
Figure S2b
. Two reduction reactions occur at 1.1 and 0.6 V. For the as-prepared MoS
3
/r-GO electrode during the first formation cycling (
Figure
3
b), lithiation peaks are observed at 1.59, 1.45, and 0.67 V, corresponding to the phase transformation of MoS
3
to metallic Mo and Li
2
S by intercalation and conversion, respectively (
eqs 1
–
3
,
Scheme S1
(I–III)).
(33)
For the delithiation, two oxidation peaks appear at 1.44 and 1.89 V, corresponding to oxidation of Mo to Mo
4+
and Mo
6+
, respectively (
eqs 4
and
5
,
Scheme S1
(IV and V)).
(34)
In addition, the oxidation peak for Li
2
S is observed at 2.31 V (
eq 6
,
Scheme S1
(VI)).
(1)
(2)
(3)
(4)
(5)
(6)

div.div:
However, from the second cycle (
Figure
3
c), the lithiation of MoS
3
to MoS
2
and Li
2
S (
eq 1
) is dramatically decreased and the intercalation of MoS
2
(
eq 2
) significantly increased, which indicates that during the initial formation cycles the lithiated MoS
3
starts to decompose into Li
x
MoS
2
and Li
2
S. Therefore, the reversible reaction is composed of both lithiations of
eqs 7
and
8
(
Scheme S1
(VII and VIII)) and delithiation of
eq 9
(
Scheme S1
(IV–VI)), and during this conversion, the microsized amorphous MoS
3
can be recombined to a relatively stable MoS
2
crystalline nanostructure with Li
2
S. Consequently, amorphous MoS
3
is rearranged into metallic Mo and Li
2
S, and the Mo and S are recombined to nanosized crystalline MoS
2
reversibly.
(7)
(8)
(9)

On the basis of the above-derived equations, fully repetitive lithiation and delithiation reactions lead to the conversion of amorphous MoS
3
to crystalline MoS
2
and Li
2
S and the pulverization of a microsheet into nanoscale sheets by repeatedly decomposing and recombining bonds between Mo and S (
Figure
3
d).

To improve the stability of the material more, we form a high-quality SEI layer with nanoscale thickness on the pulverized sheet by way of controlling the potential with a specific electrolyte additive (fluoroethylene carbonate, FEC).
(21)
The electrochemical reaction with the FEC additive is performed between 0.05 and 3.0 V at 0.5 A g
–1
(
Figure
4
a). The capacity in the MoS
3
/r-GO electrode with the FEC additive shows a similar tendency: a gradual capacity increase with cycling as is observed without the additive (
Figure
2
a). However, it is notable that the electrode with FEC additive has no capacity fading during the initial cycling, indicating that the FEC can impede loss of cyclable lithium ions by forming a thin and highly conductive SEI.
(35)
From the highly magnified HR-TEM image of the electrode after 100 cycles in
Figure
4
b, pulverized sheets covered by an ultrathin film with a thickness of 0.9–1.0 nm are observed. In addition,
Figure
4
c shows XPS peaks of the 100 cycled MoS
3
/r-GO with FEC additive for the carbon 1s orbital, and two peaks were detected at 289–292 eV and 285–287 eV as well as the main C–C bonding peak detected at 284.5 eV. Both peaks correspond to highly oxidized carbon compounds (O–C═O: 289.0 eV, −R–CH
2
OCO
2
Li: 288–289 eV, −Li
2
CO
3
: 290 eV, −R–CH
2
OCO
2
Li: 290–291 eV) and low oxidized carbon compounds (C–O: 285.0 eV and C═O: 286.5 eV), respectively,
(21,35)
and both are major compounds of SEI in LIBs. Specifically, the SEI with low oxidized carbon compounds has better properties, namely, relatively high conductivity and low lithium consumption (thin and high-quality SEI) when compared with highly oxidized ones (thick and low quality).
(21)
It is notable that for the electrode formed with FEC, after 100 cycles the relative intensity of the highly oxidized peak compared to the C–C peak (17.6%) is similar to that of the uncycled sample (11.8%) (
Figure S7a
). In contrast, without FEC (
Figure S7b
) the intensity ratio is more than 3 times higher (58.9% w/o FEC, 17.6% w/FEC). This difference suggests that the FEC additive supports the formation of a high-quality and thin SEI. Furthermore, the XPS depth profile in
Figure
4
d shows that the atomic weight percent of carbon decreases, whereas those of Mo and S increase with increasing etching time. The detection of Mo and S, despite the short etching time of 10 s, also supports that the SEI layer is ultrathin (thickness ≤1 nm) as observed in the TEM image (
Figure
4
b).

div.p:
Figure 4. Cycling performance, HR-TEM images, XPS, and XPS depth profile for a MoS
3
/r-GO half-cell with electrolyte additive (FEC) and schematic illustration and electrochemical performance of the designed full-cell employing a lithiated Si/C anode and stabilized (after
in situ
pulverization) MoS
3
/r-GO cathode. (a) The half-cell test for the MoS
3
/r-GO for the cathode with electrolyte additive (FEC) is carried out between 0.05 and 3.0 V at 25 °C. (b) HR-TEM bright field image of the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer formed on the MoS
3
/r-GO cathode after 100 cycles. (c) XPS surface analysis result for C 1s of the 100 cycled MoS
3
/r-GO electrode with FEC. (d) XPS depth profile of the cycled MoS
3
/r-GO cathode. (e) The half-cell test for the MoS
3
/r-GO for the cathode with FEC is carried out between 0.05 and 3.0 V, respectively, at 25 °C. The cyclability and Coulombic efficiency (CE) of the MoS
3
/r-GO half-cell are measured at 5.0 A g
–1
(5C based on average reversible capacity (∼1000 mAh g
–1
)) over 2500 cycles. (f) Schematic of the designed full-cell employing a lithiated Si/C-MoS
3
/r-GO electrode. The full-cell is tested between 0.5 and 2.8 V at 0.25 A g
–1
. (g) The cyclability and CE of the full-cell measured at 0.25 A g
–1
for 150 cycles. The specific capacity is calculated based on the MoS
3
/r-GO cathode. Scale bars: 5 nm (b).

div.div:
Figure
4
e shows long-term cyclability results of the electrochemically treated MoS
3
/r-GO electrode with high-quality SEI at high specific current (5.0 A g
–1
), which is about the 5C-rate based on average reversible capacity. The initial capacity is about 700 mAh g
–1
, but subsequently the capacity increases to 1200 mAh g
–1
after 1000 cycles and slightly decreases to 850–900 mAh g
–1
for the next 1500 cycles. Afterward, the capacity of the cell remains stable for up to 2500 cycles without capacity fading; the average Coulombic efficiency (CE) during the stable cycles is 99.998%. Afterward, the capacity exhibits a slight decrease from the 2500th cycle to the 5000th cycle (
Figure S8
).

In order to confirm the feasibility of as-prepared MoS
3
/r-GO for use as a high-capacity cathode for LIBs, we design a full-cell battery employing the stabilized MoS
3
/r-GO (after
in situ
pulverization) as a cathode with a lithiated silicon–carbon (Si/C) composite electrode
(22)
as an anode, as shown in the schematic of
Figure
4
f.
Figure S9
shows the cyclability of a Si/C half-cell tested at 0.5 A g
–1
. The Si/C half-cell has a high initial capacity of 3531 mAh g
–1
but a large irreversible capacity loss (ICL) due to the formation of SEI. Therefore, to prevent rapid degradation of the full-cell by ICL of the Si/C anode, we used a stabilized Si/C electrode after the third lithiation (
Figure S10
) for the full-cell.
Figure
4
g shows the cycling performance of the full-cell employing a lithiated Si/C anode and a MoS
3
/r-GO cathode, which is tested between 0.5 and 2.8 V at 0.25 A g
–1
. The full-cells using the unstabilized MoS
3
/r-GO cathodes before the completion of the
in situ
pulverization (
e
.
g
., cycled during 0, 20, and 50 cycles) exhibit a severe ICL, low stability, and rapid degradation due to irreversible reaction of active material (
Figure S11
). In contrast, as shown in
Figure
4
g, the cycling performance of the full-cell employing enough stabilized MoS
3
/r-GO cathode (
e
.
g
., after 800 cycles) shows a high initial capacity of 1612 mAh g
–1
. Although the initial capacity gradually decreases for the initial 11 cycles due to the formation of an SEI and the consumption of cyclable lithium ions,
(25)
the cell maintains a very stable capacity of approximately 1150 mAh g
–1
during 150 cycles (the capacity decreases slightly after 150 cycles, but it still retains a high capacity of 953 mAh g
–1
after 250 cycle,
Figure S8b
). It is notable that the full-cell battery designed in this work shows a 6–9 times higher capacity (1150 mAh g
–1
) and a 3–5 times higher energy density (1725 Wh kg
–1
/7100 Wh L
–1
) than the presently commercialized LIBs.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In order to substitute for the problematic pure sulfur-based cathodes, molybdenum sulfide material with increased S content was prepared by a simple chemical method to use as the cathode in LIBs. A two-dimensional MoS
3
/r-GO was fabricated using the oxygen functional group of GO for facile insertion and extraction of lithium ions and mitigation of structural decay. In addition, to enhance the stability and performance of LIBs, the microsized MoS
3
sheet was intentionally pulverized into nanoscale MoS
2
sheets (5–7 nm in diameter) and an ultrathin SEI layer (0.9–1.0 nm) was formed on the surface
via in situ
electrochemical reactions. It results in an approximately 200% increase in a capacity at the same C-rate during formation cycles and long-term stabilization after stabilization of sheet size to nanometer (5–7 nm) by decreasing the charge-transfer resistance and alleviating volume expansion.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3:
Fabrication of MoS
3
/r-GO Composite for a Cathode
div.div:
Graphene oxide (GO) was prepared by oxidization of natural graphite powder using a modified Hummers method.
(36)
The graphite (Aldrich) was dispersed in sulfuric acid (H
2
SO
4
, 98 wt %) by stirring, with potassium permanganate (KMnO
4
, 30 wt %) slowly added to the mixture. Then, the mixture temperature was held at 60 °C for 6 h before cooling down to room temperature. Next, distilled water and hydrogen peroxide (H
2
O
2
, 30 wt %) were added to remove the residual reactant. The mixture was collected by centrifugation followed by freeze-drying of the product at −45 °C for 24 h. Second, the as-prepared GO and ammonium tetrathiomolybdate ((NH
4
)
2
MoS
4
) were dispersed in deionized water with stirring at room temperature. Hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37 wt %) was separately added to the mixture. After the evolution of hydrogen sulfide (H
2
S) gas was completed, the resulting product was centrifuged at 7000 rpm for 10 min followed by washing with deionized water, isopropyl alcohol, and acetone several times to remove residual acid. Finally, the gel-like MoS
3
/r-GO was freeze-dried at −45 °C for 24 h and then used as cathode material for a LIB. The MoS
3
/r-GO powder, activated carbon (SuperP by TIMCAL), and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVdF) binder were mixed together using a mass ratio of 80:10:10 wt %, respectively, in an
N
-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solution to prepare the slurry used for casting the electrode. The as-prepared slurry was cast onto a copper foil. The electrode was characterized after drying overnight at 80 °C under vacuum.

div.h3: Fabrication of the Si/C Composite for an Anode
div.div: Nanosized silicon powder (average particle size: 100 nm), graphite powder, activated carbon, and poly(acrylic acid) (PAA) binder (Aldrich) were mixed together in a deionized water solution to prepare the slurry used for casting the electrode. The slurry was coated onto a copper foil using a doctor blade. The electrode was dried overnight at 80 °C under vacuum before characterization as the anode for a full-cell.

A half-cell was assembled using 1 M lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF
6
) in ethylene carbonate:diethyl carbonate (1:1, v/v %) as electrolyte, a polymer separator (Celgard 2400), MoS
3
/r-GO as cathode, and a lithium metal foil (Aldrich) as counter electrode in a glovebox filled with Ar; the 2032-type coin cell configuration was used. Then 60 μL of the electrolyte was added to each cell with 0.53 mg cm
–2
of active material in the cathode. The assembled cell was equilibrated for 12 h at room temperature. To put the cyclable lithium into the full-cell, the Si/C anode was lithiated to 0.05 V at 0.25 A g
–1
before fabrication of the full-cell; the full-cell was assembled using the lithiated Si/C anode and MoS
3
/r-GO cathode. All the assembly conditions were the same as those used for the half-cells. The thickness of the electrode was 34 μm. In addition, for the MoS
3
/r-GO electrode with a higher areal density of 0.70 mg cm
–2
, the rate-capability and cyclability were tested at 1.25 A g
–1
(
Figure S12
).

To measure the electrochemical properties of the LIB employing various electrodes, charge–discharge profile, CV, and EIS tests were carried out. Cycling tests were conducted using a battery cycler system (WBCS 3000S, WonATech) at room temperature (∼23 °C). For testing the rate capability, half-cells incorporating the MoS
3
/r-GO cathode were charged to 3.0 V and discharged to 0.05 V at varying specific currents ranging from 0.25 to 5.0 A g
–1
. In addition, a high-rate cycling performance test was conducted at 5.0 A g
–1
, which is a 5C rate based on the average operating capacity of the cathode. The CV test was carried out using a potentiostat system (Solartron Analytical 1470E) between 0.05 and 3.0 V
Li+/Li
at a slow scan rate (0.05 mV s
–1
). The EIS test for the half-cell was conducted using a potentiostat system (VSP, Bio-Logics). The frequency was scanned from 1.0 MHz to 0.01 Hz using a 5.0 mV amplitude. The values for the varying resistances were determined using an EIS fitting program (Z view, Scribner Associates).

The morphology of the prepared MoS
3
/r-GO composite was observed using a SEM equipped with an EDS (S-4700 with EMAX system, Hitachi) and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM, Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin, FEI). The crystal structure of the material was characterized by XRD (Alpha-1, PANalytical). To characterize the active material of the electrode, the cell was opened in an Ar-filled glovebox and then washed in dimethyl carbonate to remove salts. HR-TEM and XPS (K-Alpha, Thermo Fisher) were used to observe the change in morphology and chemical composition in the active material induced by cycling. The XPS depth profile was obtained by etching with an Ar-ion beam as a function of time (seconds).

The authors declare that the data supporting the findings of this study are available within the article and its
Supporting Information
files. All other relevant data supporting the findings of this study are available on request.

A review of current scientific issues underpinning Li batteries and elec. double-layer capacitors. Energy-storage technologies, including elec. double-layer capacitors and rechargeable batteries, have attracted significant attention for applications in portable electronic devices, elec. vehicles, bulk electricity storage at power stations, and load leveling of renewable sources, such as solar energy and wind power. Transforming Li batteries and elec. double-layer capacitors requires a step change in the science underpinning these devices, including the discovery of new materials, new electrochem., and an increased understanding of the processes on which the devices depend.

This review covers key technol. developments and scientific challenges for a broad range of Li-ion battery electrodes. Periodic table and potential/capacity plots are used to compare many families of suitable materials. Performance characteristics, current limitations, and recent breakthroughs in the development of com. intercalation materials such as lithium cobalt oxide (LCO), lithium nickel cobalt manganese oxide (NCM), lithium nickel cobalt aluminum oxide (NCA), lithium iron phosphate (LFP), lithium titanium oxide (LTO) and others are contrasted with that of conversion materials, such as alloying anodes (Si, Ge, Sn, etc.), chalcogenides (S, Se, Te), and metal halides (F, Cl, Br, I). New polyanion cathode materials are also discussed. The cost, abundance, safety, Li and electron transport, volumetric expansion, material dissoln., and surface reactions for each type of electrode materials are described. Both general and specific strategies to overcome the current challenges are covered and categorized.

Seh, Zhi Wei; Sun, Yongming; Zhang, Qianfan; Cui, Yi

Due to their high energy d. and low material cost, lithium-sulfur batteries represent a promising energy storage system for a multitude of emerging applications, ranging from stationary grid storage to mobile elec. vehicles. This review aims to summarize major developments in the field of lithium-sulfur batteries, starting from an overview of their electrochem., tech. challenges and potential solns., along with some theor. calcn. results to advance our understanding of the material interactions involved. Next, we examine the most extensively-used design strategy: encapsulation of sulfur cathodes in carbon host materials. Other emerging host materials, such as polymeric and inorg. materials, are discussed as well. This is followed by a survey of novel battery configurations, including the use of lithium sulfide cathodes and lithium polysulfide catholytes, as well as recent burgeoning efforts in the modification of separators and protection of lithium metal anodes. Finally, we conclude with an outlook section to offer some insight on the future directions and prospects of lithium-sulfur batteries.

A highly ordered nanostructured carbon-sulphur cathode for lithium-sulphur batteries
Ji, Xiulei; Lee, Kyu Tae; Nazar, Linda F.

The Li-S batteries have been studied for over 2 decades, as it offers the possibility of high gravimetric capacities and theor. energy densities ranging up to a factor of 5 beyond conventional Li-ion systems. The feasibility to approach such capacities by creating highly ordered interwoven composites was studied. The conductive mesoporous C framework constrains S nanofiller growth within its channels and generates essential elec. contact to the insulating S. The structure provides access to Li+ ingress/egress for reactivity with the S. It is possible that the kinetic inhibition to diffusion within the framework and the sorption properties of the C aid in trapping the polysulfides formed during redox. Polymer modification of the C surface further provides a chem. gradient that retards diffusion of these large anions out of the electrode, thus facilitating more complete reaction. Reversible capacities up to 1320 mA-h/g are attained. The assembly process is simple and broadly applicable, conceptually providing new opportunities for materials scientists for tailored design that can be extended to many different electrode materials.

A review of principles, history, and tech. challenges of Li-S batteries. Sulfur and lithium sulfide composite cathode materials are discussed. Significant attention is paid to the characterization techniques used and the mechanistic understanding gained. The electrolyte, separators, anodes, and binders used in Li-S batteries are evaluated. Novel cell configurations including carbon interlayers between the sulfur cathode and the separator are described. Guidance for future development in the field is provided.

Sulfur (S) encapsulated in porous carbon nanofibers (CNFs) was synthesized via electrospinning, carbonization and soln.-based chem. reaction-deposition method. The chem. reaction-deposition strategy provides intimate contact between the S and the CNFs. This would not necessarily be the case for other reported methods, such as ball milling and thermal treatment. These novel porous carbon nanofiber-sulfur (CNF-S) nanocomposites with various S loadings showed high reversible capacity, good discharge capacity retention and enhanced rate capability when they were used as cathodes in rechargeable Li/S cells. We demonstrated here that an electrode prepd. from a porous CNF-S nanocomposite with 42 wt% S maintains a stable discharge capacity of about 1400 mA h g-1 at 0.05 C, 1100 mA h g-1 at 0.1 C and 900 mA h g-1 at 0.2 C. We attribute the good electrochem. performance to the high elec. cond. and the extremely high surface area of the CNFs that homogeneously disperse and immobilize S on their porous structures, alleviating the polysulfide shuttle phenomenon. SEM measurements showed that the porous CNF structures remained nearly unchanged even after 30 cycles' discharging/charging at 0.05 C.

Rui, Xianhong; Tan, Huiteng; Yan, Qingyu

(

A review. Advanced electrodes with a high energy d. at high power are urgently needed for high-performance energy storage devices, including lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and supercapacitors (SCs), to fulfill the requirements of future electrochem. power sources for applications such as in hybrid elec./plug-in-hybrid (HEV/PHEV) vehicles. Metal sulfides with unique phys. and chem. properties, as well as high specific capacity/capacitance, which are typically multiple times higher than that of the carbon/graphite-based materials, are currently studied as promising electrode materials. However, the implementation of these sulfide electrodes in practical applications is hindered by their inferior rate performance and cycling stability. Nanostructures offering the advantages of high surface-to-vol. ratios, favorable transport properties, and high freedom for the vol. change upon ion insertion/extn. and other reactions, present an opportunity to build next-generation LIBs and SCs. Thus, the development of novel concepts in material research to achieve new nanostructures paves the way for improved electrochem. performance. Herein, we summarize recent advances in nanostructured metal sulfides, such as iron sulfides, copper sulfides, cobalt sulfides, nickel sulfides, manganese sulfides, molybdenum sulfides, tin sulfides, with zero-, one-, two-, and three-dimensional morphologies for LIB and SC applications. In addn., the recently emerged concept of incorporating conductive matrixes, esp. graphene, with metal sulfide nanomaterials will also be highlighted. Finally, some remarks are made on the challenges and perspectives for the future development of metal sulfide-based LIB and SC devices.

Direct Studies on the Lithium-Storage Mechanism of Molybdenum Disulfide
Su Qingmei; Wang Shixin; Du Gaohui; Xu Bingshe; Su Qingmei; Feng Miao; Du Gaohui; Xu Bingshe
Scientific reports
(
2017
),
7
(
1
),
7275
ISSN:
.
Transition metal sulfides are regarded as a type of high-performance anode materials for lithium ion batteries (LIBs). However, their electrochemical process and lithium-storage mechanism are complicated and remain controversial. This work is intended to give the direct observation on the electrochemical behavior and find out the lithium-storage mechanism of molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) using in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM). We find that single-crystalline MoS2 nanosheets convert to Mo nanograins (~2 nm) embedded in Li2S matrix after the first full lithiation. After the delithiation, the Mo nanograins and Li2S transform to a large number of lamellar MoS2 nanocrystals. The discharge-charge cycling of MoS2 in LIBs is found to be a fully reversible conversion between MoS2 and Mo/Li2S rather than the electrochemical conversion between S and Li2S proposed by many researchers. The in situ real-time characterization results give direct evidence and profound insights into the lithium-storage mechanism of MoS2 as anode in LIBs.

Many problems assocd. with Li-S and Na-S batteries essentially root in the generation of their sol. polysulfide intermediates. While conventional wisdom mainly focuses on trapping polysulfides at the cathode using various functional materials, few strategies are available at present to fully resolve or circumvent this long-standing issue. We propose the concept of S-equiv. cathode materials, and demonstrate the great potential of amorphous MoS3 as such a material for room-temp. Li-S and Na-S batteries. In Li-S batteries, MoS3 exhibits S-like behavior with large reversible specific capacity, excellent cycle life, and the possibility to achieve high areal capacity. Most remarkably, it is also fully cyclable in the carbonate electrolyte under a relatively high temp. of 55°. MoS3 can also be used as the cathode material of even more challenging Na-S batteries to enable decent capacity and good cycle life. Operando x-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) expts. are carried out to track the structural evolution of MoS3. It largely preserves its chain-like structure during repetitive battery cycling without generating any free polysulfide intermediates.

Sn materials offer high theor. capacities in lithium ion batteries, but they must have good cycling stability and high rate-capability in order to be commercialized. Complex and costly material treatments of Sn have been effective in reducing capacity fade, but conventionally produced bare Sn is desired for reducing cost. One simple method is to form a high-quality solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on Sn particles with low resistance and high passivation. Fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) added to the electrolyte forms a protective and less-resistant SEI on Sn particles during the in-situ electrochem. SEI formation cycle. FEC is a good oxidizing agent that removes highly oxidized carbon compds. and makes a SEI thinner during an oxidn. process (delithiation) of SEI formation cycle. The high-quality SEI greatly improves the rate-capability and capacity of nano-sized bare Sn electrodes without any treatments: minimal capacity fade (0.014% cycle-1) at 320 mA h g-1 (1.3 C) for 150 cycles. The mitigating effect of FEC on capacity fade is not seen with electrodes fabricated from micro-scale (0.1∼0.2 μm) Sn. The long lithium-ion diffusion path makes these micro-sized materials susceptible to decrepitation during repeated vol. changes.

Exploiting multiferroic BiFeO3 thin films in spintronic devices requires deterministic and robust control of both internal magnetoelec. coupling in BiFeO3, as well as exchange coupling of its antiferromagnetic order to a ferromagnetic overlayer. Previous reports utilized approaches based on multi-step ferroelec. switching with multiple ferroelec. domains. Because domain walls can be responsible for fatigue, contain localized charges intrinsically or via defects, and present problems for device reproducibility and scaling, an alternative approach using a monodomain magnetoelec. state with single-step switching is desirable. Here we demonstrate room temp., deterministic and robust, exchange coupling between monodomain BiFeO3 films and Co overlayer that is intrinsic (i.e., not dependent on domain walls). Direct coupling between BiFeO3 antiferromagnetic order and Co magnetization is obsd., with ∼ 90° in-plane Co moment rotation upon single-step switching that is reproducible for hundreds of cycles. This has important consequences for practical, low power non-volatile magnetoelec. devices utilizing BiFeO3.

Amorphous MoS3 and poorly cryst. MoS2 were studied using IR and Raman spectroscopies. While poorly cryst. MoS2 exhibits sharp IR bands at 385 and 470 cm-1, broad bands at 287, 335, 373, and 522 cm-1 were obsd. for the amorphous MoS3. In contrast to poorly cryst. MoS2 where sharp Raman peaks were measured at 384 and 408 cm-1, the Raman spectrum of amorphous MoS3 showed broad peaks at 215, 317, 431, and 528 cm-1. The band profiles of both the IR and Raman spectra of the MoS3 sample indicate the amorphous nature of the material. This is consistent with results obtained by other techniques. The comparison of the Raman spectrum of MoS3 and that of amorphous MoS2 reported in the literature indicates that local bondings in these materials are dissimilar. The presence of broad bands at 522 cm-1 in IR and 528 cm-1 in Raman spectra of MoS3 is evidence for polysulfide bonds indicated by the x-ray diffraction spectrum of the material. These results support a chain-like structural model for amorphous MoS3 similar to that for cryst. MS3 (M = Ti, Zr, Hf, Nb, Ta, and U). The thermal stability of MoS3 and the effect of laser power on the Raman spectrum of MoS3 were also studied.

High quality reduced graphene oxide (rGO) nanosheets were prepd. from natural graphite through oxidn. followed by solvothermal redn. method. The morphol., structure and compn. of graphene oxide (GO) and rGO were characterized by SEM, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Raman spectrum, X-ray diffraction (XRD), and XPS. The electrochem. performances of rGO nanosheets as anode materials for lithium-ion batteries were evaluated in coin-type cells vs. metallic lithium. Results showed that the obtained rGO exhibited a higher reversible specific capacity of 561 mAh g-1 at a c.d. of 100 mA g-1 and 166 mAh g-1 at a c.d. of 4000 mA g-1. The excellent cycling stability and high-rate capability of rGO as anodes of lithium-ion battery were attributed to its few layers structure, large-size sheet, and fast transport kinetics of Li-ion and electron on the interface of electrolyte/electrode.

The design of a Li-ion full cell battery using a nano silicon and nano multi-layer graphene composite anode
Eom, KwangSup; Joshi, Tapesh; Bordes, Arnaud; Do, Inhwan; Fuller, Thomas F.

In this study, a Si-graphene composite, which is composed of nanosized Si particles and nanosized multi-layer graphene particles, and micro-sized multilayer graphene plate conductor, was used as the anode for Li-ion battery. The Si-graphene electrode showed the high capacity and stable cyclability at charge/discharge rate of C/2 in half cell tests. Nickel cobalt aluminum material (NCA) was used as a cathode in the full cell to evaluate the practicality of the new Si-graphene material. Although the Si-graphene anode has more capacity than the NCA cathode in this designed full cell, the Si-graphene anode had a greater effect on the full-cell performance due to its large initial irreversible capacity loss and continuous SEI formation during cycling. When fluoroethylene carbonate was added to the electrolyte, the cyclability of the full cell was much improved due to less SEI formation, which was confirmed by the decreases in the 1st irreversible capacity loss, overpotential for the 1st lithiation, and the resistance of the SEI.

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy study of a lithium/sulfur battery: modeling and analysis of capacity fading
Deng, Zhaofeng; Zhang, Zhian; Lai, Yanqing; Liu, Jin; Li, Jie; Liu, Yexiang

Electrochemical Society

The electrochem. behavior of a lithium/sulfur battery was studied by electrochem. impedance spectroscopy. An impedance model based on the anal. of electrochem. impedance spectra as a function of temp. and depth of discharge was developed. Then, by monitoring the evolution of impedance during the cycling process, the capacity fading mechanism of lithium/sulfur battery was investigated. The results show that the semicircle at the middle frequency of the electrochem. impedance spectra is ascribed to the charge-transfer process and the semicircle at high frequency is related to the interphase contact resistance. Furthermore, electrolyte resistance, interphase contact resistance, and charge-transfer resistance vary with cycle no. in different manners, and the charge-transfer resistance is the key factor contributing to the capacity fading of lithium/sulfur battery.

Formation of a solid/electrolyte interface (SEI) on the surface of graphite in Li/graphite batteries was studied by electrochem. impedance spectroscopy (EIS). EIS of the cells vary considerably with cell voltage. In particular, resistance, Rsei of the SEI increases with lithiation and decreases reversibly during de-lithiation in the voltage range 0.15 to 0.04 V. According to the change of Rsei during the 1st lithiation, the formation of the SEI occurs above and below 0.15 V. The SEI formed in the above 0.15 V is less conductive, and that formed below 0.15 V is highly conductive. Ionic cond. of the preliminarily formed SEI is affected by the solvents and salts of the electrolyte. The Rsei increases in the order LiBF4 > LiSO3CF3 > LiBOB > LiPF6 for salt, and NMP > EMC > MB for solvent. Addn. of vinylene carbonate to the electrolyte increases the Rsei.

Structural Evolution of Electrochemically Lithiated MoS2 Nanosheets and the Role of Carbon Additive in Li-Ion Batteries
George, Chandramohan; Morris, Andrew J.; Modarres, Mohammad H.; De Volder, Michael
Chemistry of Materials
(
2016
),
28
(
20
),
7304-7310
CODEN:
CMATEX
; ISSN:
0897-4756
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Understanding the structure and phase changes assocd. with conversion-type materials is key to optimizing their electrochem. performance in Li-ion batteries. For example, molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) offers a capacity up to 3-fold higher (∼1 Ah/g) than the currently used graphite anodes, but they suffer from limited Coulombic efficiency and capacity fading. The lack of insights into the structural dynamics induced by electrochem. conversion of MoS2 still hampers its implementation in high energy-d. batteries. Here, by combining ab initio d.-functional theory (DFT) simulation with electrochem. anal., we found new sulfur-enriched intermediates that progressively insulate MoS2 electrodes and cause instability from the first discharge cycle. Because of this, the choice of conductive additives is crit. for the battery performance. We investigate the mechanistic role of carbon additive by comparing equal loading of std. Super P carbon powder and carbon nanotubes (CNTs). The latter offer a nearly 2-fold increase in capacity and a 45% redn. in resistance along with Coulombic efficiency of over 90%. These insights into the phase changes during MoS2 conversion reactions and stabilization methods provide new solns. for implementing cost-effective metal sulfide electrodes, including Li-S systems in high energy-d. batteries.

Supernormal Conversion Anode Consisting of High-Density MoS2 Bubbles Wrapped in Thin Carbon Network by Self-Sulfuration of Polyoxometalate Complex
Wang, Peiyuan; Tian, Jing; Hu, Jiulin; Zhou, Xuejun; Li, Chilin

.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Large-capacity conversion electrodes are highly required to raise the energy d. of batteries. However, their undesired phase segregation and vol. expansion during cycling lead to the motivation for nanofabrication and nanochem. of active species in order to decrease "dead mass" and promote better construction of conductive networks. However, the inactivity of the conductive skeleton and loose nanostructure would compromise the energy d. of the electrode. The integration of large-sized (high-d.) grains into an electroactive conductive network in a compact way is still a big challenge. Here we report a proof-of-concept prototype consisting of unusual MoS2 solid bubbles of hundreds of nanometers in size, which are conformally encapsulated by thin-layer carbon. The seamless welding between this carbon coating and the surrounding broader carbon substrate can effectively avoid the peel-off of active species and breakage of the conductive network. This MoS2-C composite is achieved by simultaneous self-sulfuration and self-carbonization of a polyoxometalate (POM)-based chelate, and its Li-storage performance is superior to most MoS2-based anodes even with ultrathin 2D nanosheets. Partially benefiting from the electroactivity of a dithiooxamide (DTO)-derivate carbon network, the reversible capacity of MoS2-C by pyrolyzing the POM-DTO chelate can reach 1500-2000 mAh/g at 0.5-1 A/g even after 700 cycles and be maintained around 1000 mAh/g under as high as 10-20 A/g.

Self-assembly of hierarchical MoSx/CNT nanocomposites (2<x<3): towards high performance anode materials for lithium ion batteries
Shi Yumeng; Wang Ye; Wong Jen It; Tan Alex Yuan Sheng; Hsu Chang-Lung; Li Lain-Jong; Lu Yi-Chun; Yang Hui Ying
Scientific reports
(
2013
),
3
(
),

ISSN:
.
Two dimension (2D) layered molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has emerged as a promising candidate for the anode material in lithium ion batteries (LIBs). Herein, 2D MoSx (2 ≤ x ≤ 3) nanosheet-coated 1D multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) nanocomposites with hierarchical architecture were synthesized via a high-throughput solvent thermal method under low temperature at 200°C. The unique hierarchical nanostructures with MWNTs backbone and nanosheets of MoSx have significantly promoted the electrode performance in LIBs. Every single MoSx nanosheet interconnect to MWNTs centers with maximized exposed electrochemical active sites, which significantly enhance ion diffusion efficiency and accommodate volume expansion during the electrochemical reaction. A remarkably high specific capacity (i.e., > 1000 mAh/g) was achieved at the current density of 50 mA g(-1), which is much higher than theoretical numbers for either MWNTs or MoS2 along (~372 and ~670 mAh/g, respectively). We anticipate 2D nanosheets/1D MWNTs nanocomposites will be promising materials in new generation practical LIBs.

Traditional lithium-ion batteries that are based on layered Li intercalation electrode materials are limited by the intrinsically low theor. capacities of both electrodes and cannot meet the increasing demand for energy. A facile route for the synthesis of a new type of composite nanofibers, namely carbon nanofibers decorated with molybdenum disulfide sheets (
[email protected]
), is now reported. A synergistic effect was obsd. for the two-component anode, triggering new electrochem. processes for lithium storage, with a persistent oxidn. from Mo (or MoS2) to MoS3 in the repeated charge processes, leading to an ascending capacity upon cycling. The composite exhibits unprecedented electrochem. behavior with high specific capacity, good cycling stability, and superior high-rate capability, suggesting its potential application in high-energy lithium-ion batteries.

Etacheri, Vinodkumar; Haik, Ortal; Goffer, Yossi; Roberts, Gregory A.; Stefan, Ionel C.; Fasching, Rainier; Aurbach, Doron

The effect of FEC as a co-solvent on the electrochem. performance and surface chem. of silicon nanowire (SiNW) anodes was thoroughly studied. Enhanced electrochem. performance was obsd. for SiNW anodes in alkyl carbonates electrolyte solns. contg. fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC). Reduced irreversible capacity losses accompanied by enhanced and stable reversible capacities over prolonged cycling were achieved with FEC-contg. electrolyte solns. TEM studies provided evidence for the complete and incomplete lithiation of SiNW's in FEC-contg. and FEC-free electrolyte solns., resp. SEM results proved the formation of much thinner and compact surface films on SiNW's in FEC-contg. solns. However, thicker surface films were identified for SiNW electrodes cycled in FEC-free solns. SiNW electrodes develop lower impedance in electrolyte solns. contg. FEC in contrast to std. (FEC-free) solns. The surface chem. of SiNW electrodes cycled in FEC-modified and std. electrolytes were studied using XPS and FTIR spectroscopy. The impact of FEC as a co-solvent on the electrochem. behavior of SiNW electrodes is discussed herein in light of the spectroscopic and microscopic studies.

This review covers key technol. developments and scientific challenges for a broad range of Li-ion battery electrodes. Periodic table and potential/capacity plots are used to compare many families of suitable materials. Performance characteristics, current limitations, and recent breakthroughs in the development of com. intercalation materials such as lithium cobalt oxide (LCO), lithium nickel cobalt manganese oxide (NCM), lithium nickel cobalt aluminum oxide (NCA), lithium iron phosphate (LFP), lithium titanium oxide (LTO) and others are contrasted with that of conversion materials, such as alloying anodes (Si, Ge, Sn, etc.), chalcogenides (S, Se, Te), and metal halides (F, Cl, Br, I). New polyanion cathode materials are also discussed. The cost, abundance, safety, Li and electron transport, volumetric expansion, material dissoln., and surface reactions for each type of electrode materials are described. Both general and specific strategies to overcome the current challenges are covered and categorized.

Due to their high energy d. and low material cost, lithium-sulfur batteries represent a promising energy storage system for a multitude of emerging applications, ranging from stationary grid storage to mobile elec. vehicles. This review aims to summarize major developments in the field of lithium-sulfur batteries, starting from an overview of their electrochem., tech. challenges and potential solns., along with some theor. calcn. results to advance our understanding of the material interactions involved. Next, we examine the most extensively-used design strategy: encapsulation of sulfur cathodes in carbon host materials. Other emerging host materials, such as polymeric and inorg. materials, are discussed as well. This is followed by a survey of novel battery configurations, including the use of lithium sulfide cathodes and lithium polysulfide catholytes, as well as recent burgeoning efforts in the modification of separators and protection of lithium metal anodes. Finally, we conclude with an outlook section to offer some insight on the future directions and prospects of lithium-sulfur batteries.

The Li-S batteries have been studied for over 2 decades, as it offers the possibility of high gravimetric capacities and theor. energy densities ranging up to a factor of 5 beyond conventional Li-ion systems. The feasibility to approach such capacities by creating highly ordered interwoven composites was studied. The conductive mesoporous C framework constrains S nanofiller growth within its channels and generates essential elec. contact to the insulating S. The structure provides access to Li+ ingress/egress for reactivity with the S. It is possible that the kinetic inhibition to diffusion within the framework and the sorption properties of the C aid in trapping the polysulfides formed during redox. Polymer modification of the C surface further provides a chem. gradient that retards diffusion of these large anions out of the electrode, thus facilitating more complete reaction. Reversible capacities up to 1320 mA-h/g are attained. The assembly process is simple and broadly applicable, conceptually providing new opportunities for materials scientists for tailored design that can be extended to many different electrode materials.

Sulfur (S) encapsulated in porous carbon nanofibers (CNFs) was synthesized via electrospinning, carbonization and soln.-based chem. reaction-deposition method. The chem. reaction-deposition strategy provides intimate contact between the S and the CNFs. This would not necessarily be the case for other reported methods, such as ball milling and thermal treatment. These novel porous carbon nanofiber-sulfur (CNF-S) nanocomposites with various S loadings showed high reversible capacity, good discharge capacity retention and enhanced rate capability when they were used as cathodes in rechargeable Li/S cells. We demonstrated here that an electrode prepd. from a porous CNF-S nanocomposite with 42 wt% S maintains a stable discharge capacity of about 1400 mA h g-1 at 0.05 C, 1100 mA h g-1 at 0.1 C and 900 mA h g-1 at 0.2 C. We attribute the good electrochem. performance to the high elec. cond. and the extremely high surface area of the CNFs that homogeneously disperse and immobilize S on their porous structures, alleviating the polysulfide shuttle phenomenon. SEM measurements showed that the porous CNF structures remained nearly unchanged even after 30 cycles' discharging/charging at 0.05 C.

A review. Advanced electrodes with a high energy d. at high power are urgently needed for high-performance energy storage devices, including lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and supercapacitors (SCs), to fulfill the requirements of future electrochem. power sources for applications such as in hybrid elec./plug-in-hybrid (HEV/PHEV) vehicles. Metal sulfides with unique phys. and chem. properties, as well as high specific capacity/capacitance, which are typically multiple times higher than that of the carbon/graphite-based materials, are currently studied as promising electrode materials. However, the implementation of these sulfide electrodes in practical applications is hindered by their inferior rate performance and cycling stability. Nanostructures offering the advantages of high surface-to-vol. ratios, favorable transport properties, and high freedom for the vol. change upon ion insertion/extn. and other reactions, present an opportunity to build next-generation LIBs and SCs. Thus, the development of novel concepts in material research to achieve new nanostructures paves the way for improved electrochem. performance. Herein, we summarize recent advances in nanostructured metal sulfides, such as iron sulfides, copper sulfides, cobalt sulfides, nickel sulfides, manganese sulfides, molybdenum sulfides, tin sulfides, with zero-, one-, two-, and three-dimensional morphologies for LIB and SC applications. In addn., the recently emerged concept of incorporating conductive matrixes, esp. graphene, with metal sulfide nanomaterials will also be highlighted. Finally, some remarks are made on the challenges and perspectives for the future development of metal sulfide-based LIB and SC devices.

Direct Studies on the Lithium-Storage Mechanism of Molybdenum Disulfide
Su Qingmei; Wang Shixin; Du Gaohui; Xu Bingshe; Su Qingmei; Feng Miao; Du Gaohui; Xu Bingshe
Scientific reports
(

),
7
(
1
),

.
Transition metal sulfides are regarded as a type of high-performance anode materials for lithium ion batteries (LIBs). However, their electrochemical process and lithium-storage mechanism are complicated and remain controversial. This work is intended to give the direct observation on the electrochemical behavior and find out the lithium-storage mechanism of molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) using in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM). We find that single-crystalline MoS2 nanosheets convert to Mo nanograins (~2 nm) embedded in Li2S matrix after the first full lithiation. After the delithiation, the Mo nanograins and Li2S transform to a large number of lamellar MoS2 nanocrystals. The discharge-charge cycling of MoS2 in LIBs is found to be a fully reversible conversion between MoS2 and Mo/Li2S rather than the electrochemical conversion between S and Li2S proposed by many researchers. The in situ real-time characterization results give direct evidence and profound insights into the lithium-storage mechanism of MoS2 as anode in LIBs.

Many problems assocd. with Li-S and Na-S batteries essentially root in the generation of their sol. polysulfide intermediates. While conventional wisdom mainly focuses on trapping polysulfides at the cathode using various functional materials, few strategies are available at present to fully resolve or circumvent this long-standing issue. We propose the concept of S-equiv. cathode materials, and demonstrate the great potential of amorphous MoS3 as such a material for room-temp. Li-S and Na-S batteries. In Li-S batteries, MoS3 exhibits S-like behavior with large reversible specific capacity, excellent cycle life, and the possibility to achieve high areal capacity. Most remarkably, it is also fully cyclable in the carbonate electrolyte under a relatively high temp. of 55°. MoS3 can also be used as the cathode material of even more challenging Na-S batteries to enable decent capacity and good cycle life. Operando x-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) expts. are carried out to track the structural evolution of MoS3. It largely preserves its chain-like structure during repetitive battery cycling without generating any free polysulfide intermediates.

Sn materials offer high theor. capacities in lithium ion batteries, but they must have good cycling stability and high rate-capability in order to be commercialized. Complex and costly material treatments of Sn have been effective in reducing capacity fade, but conventionally produced bare Sn is desired for reducing cost. One simple method is to form a high-quality solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) on Sn particles with low resistance and high passivation. Fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) added to the electrolyte forms a protective and less-resistant SEI on Sn particles during the in-situ electrochem. SEI formation cycle. FEC is a good oxidizing agent that removes highly oxidized carbon compds. and makes a SEI thinner during an oxidn. process (delithiation) of SEI formation cycle. The high-quality SEI greatly improves the rate-capability and capacity of nano-sized bare Sn electrodes without any treatments: minimal capacity fade (0.014% cycle-1) at 320 mA h g-1 (1.3 C) for 150 cycles. The mitigating effect of FEC on capacity fade is not seen with electrodes fabricated from micro-scale (0.1∼0.2 μm) Sn. The long lithium-ion diffusion path makes these micro-sized materials susceptible to decrepitation during repeated vol. changes.

Exploiting multiferroic BiFeO3 thin films in spintronic devices requires deterministic and robust control of both internal magnetoelec. coupling in BiFeO3, as well as exchange coupling of its antiferromagnetic order to a ferromagnetic overlayer. Previous reports utilized approaches based on multi-step ferroelec. switching with multiple ferroelec. domains. Because domain walls can be responsible for fatigue, contain localized charges intrinsically or via defects, and present problems for device reproducibility and scaling, an alternative approach using a monodomain magnetoelec. state with single-step switching is desirable. Here we demonstrate room temp., deterministic and robust, exchange coupling between monodomain BiFeO3 films and Co overlayer that is intrinsic (i.e., not dependent on domain walls). Direct coupling between BiFeO3 antiferromagnetic order and Co magnetization is obsd., with ∼ 90° in-plane Co moment rotation upon single-step switching that is reproducible for hundreds of cycles. This has important consequences for practical, low power non-volatile magnetoelec. devices utilizing BiFeO3.

Amorphous MoS3 and poorly cryst. MoS2 were studied using IR and Raman spectroscopies. While poorly cryst. MoS2 exhibits sharp IR bands at 385 and 470 cm-1, broad bands at 287, 335, 373, and 522 cm-1 were obsd. for the amorphous MoS3. In contrast to poorly cryst. MoS2 where sharp Raman peaks were measured at 384 and 408 cm-1, the Raman spectrum of amorphous MoS3 showed broad peaks at 215, 317, 431, and 528 cm-1. The band profiles of both the IR and Raman spectra of the MoS3 sample indicate the amorphous nature of the material. This is consistent with results obtained by other techniques. The comparison of the Raman spectrum of MoS3 and that of amorphous MoS2 reported in the literature indicates that local bondings in these materials are dissimilar. The presence of broad bands at 522 cm-1 in IR and 528 cm-1 in Raman spectra of MoS3 is evidence for polysulfide bonds indicated by the x-ray diffraction spectrum of the material. These results support a chain-like structural model for amorphous MoS3 similar to that for cryst. MS3 (M = Ti, Zr, Hf, Nb, Ta, and U). The thermal stability of MoS3 and the effect of laser power on the Raman spectrum of MoS3 were also studied.

High quality reduced graphene oxide (rGO) nanosheets were prepd. from natural graphite through oxidn. followed by solvothermal redn. method. The morphol., structure and compn. of graphene oxide (GO) and rGO were characterized by SEM, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Raman spectrum, X-ray diffraction (XRD), and XPS. The electrochem. performances of rGO nanosheets as anode materials for lithium-ion batteries were evaluated in coin-type cells vs. metallic lithium. Results showed that the obtained rGO exhibited a higher reversible specific capacity of 561 mAh g-1 at a c.d. of 100 mA g-1 and 166 mAh g-1 at a c.d. of 4000 mA g-1. The excellent cycling stability and high-rate capability of rGO as anodes of lithium-ion battery were attributed to its few layers structure, large-size sheet, and fast transport kinetics of Li-ion and electron on the interface of electrolyte/electrode.

In this study, a Si-graphene composite, which is composed of nanosized Si particles and nanosized multi-layer graphene particles, and micro-sized multilayer graphene plate conductor, was used as the anode for Li-ion battery. The Si-graphene electrode showed the high capacity and stable cyclability at charge/discharge rate of C/2 in half cell tests. Nickel cobalt aluminum material (NCA) was used as a cathode in the full cell to evaluate the practicality of the new Si-graphene material. Although the Si-graphene anode has more capacity than the NCA cathode in this designed full cell, the Si-graphene anode had a greater effect on the full-cell performance due to its large initial irreversible capacity loss and continuous SEI formation during cycling. When fluoroethylene carbonate was added to the electrolyte, the cyclability of the full cell was much improved due to less SEI formation, which was confirmed by the decreases in the 1st irreversible capacity loss, overpotential for the 1st lithiation, and the resistance of the SEI.

The electrochem. behavior of a lithium/sulfur battery was studied by electrochem. impedance spectroscopy. An impedance model based on the anal. of electrochem. impedance spectra as a function of temp. and depth of discharge was developed. Then, by monitoring the evolution of impedance during the cycling process, the capacity fading mechanism of lithium/sulfur battery was investigated. The results show that the semicircle at the middle frequency of the electrochem. impedance spectra is ascribed to the charge-transfer process and the semicircle at high frequency is related to the interphase contact resistance. Furthermore, electrolyte resistance, interphase contact resistance, and charge-transfer resistance vary with cycle no. in different manners, and the charge-transfer resistance is the key factor contributing to the capacity fading of lithium/sulfur battery.

Formation of a solid/electrolyte interface (SEI) on the surface of graphite in Li/graphite batteries was studied by electrochem. impedance spectroscopy (EIS). EIS of the cells vary considerably with cell voltage. In particular, resistance, Rsei of the SEI increases with lithiation and decreases reversibly during de-lithiation in the voltage range 0.15 to 0.04 V. According to the change of Rsei during the 1st lithiation, the formation of the SEI occurs above and below 0.15 V. The SEI formed in the above 0.15 V is less conductive, and that formed below 0.15 V is highly conductive. Ionic cond. of the preliminarily formed SEI is affected by the solvents and salts of the electrolyte. The Rsei increases in the order LiBF4 > LiSO3CF3 > LiBOB > LiPF6 for salt, and NMP > EMC > MB for solvent. Addn. of vinylene carbonate to the electrolyte increases the Rsei.

Understanding the structure and phase changes assocd. with conversion-type materials is key to optimizing their electrochem. performance in Li-ion batteries. For example, molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) offers a capacity up to 3-fold higher (∼1 Ah/g) than the currently used graphite anodes, but they suffer from limited Coulombic efficiency and capacity fading. The lack of insights into the structural dynamics induced by electrochem. conversion of MoS2 still hampers its implementation in high energy-d. batteries. Here, by combining ab initio d.-functional theory (DFT) simulation with electrochem. anal., we found new sulfur-enriched intermediates that progressively insulate MoS2 electrodes and cause instability from the first discharge cycle. Because of this, the choice of conductive additives is crit. for the battery performance. We investigate the mechanistic role of carbon additive by comparing equal loading of std. Super P carbon powder and carbon nanotubes (CNTs). The latter offer a nearly 2-fold increase in capacity and a 45% redn. in resistance along with Coulombic efficiency of over 90%. These insights into the phase changes during MoS2 conversion reactions and stabilization methods provide new solns. for implementing cost-effective metal sulfide electrodes, including Li-S systems in high energy-d. batteries.

Large-capacity conversion electrodes are highly required to raise the energy d. of batteries. However, their undesired phase segregation and vol. expansion during cycling lead to the motivation for nanofabrication and nanochem. of active species in order to decrease "dead mass" and promote better construction of conductive networks. However, the inactivity of the conductive skeleton and loose nanostructure would compromise the energy d. of the electrode. The integration of large-sized (high-d.) grains into an electroactive conductive network in a compact way is still a big challenge. Here we report a proof-of-concept prototype consisting of unusual MoS2 solid bubbles of hundreds of nanometers in size, which are conformally encapsulated by thin-layer carbon. The seamless welding between this carbon coating and the surrounding broader carbon substrate can effectively avoid the peel-off of active species and breakage of the conductive network. This MoS2-C composite is achieved by simultaneous self-sulfuration and self-carbonization of a polyoxometalate (POM)-based chelate, and its Li-storage performance is superior to most MoS2-based anodes even with ultrathin 2D nanosheets. Partially benefiting from the electroactivity of a dithiooxamide (DTO)-derivate carbon network, the reversible capacity of MoS2-C by pyrolyzing the POM-DTO chelate can reach 1500-2000 mAh/g at 0.5-1 A/g even after 700 cycles and be maintained around 1000 mAh/g under as high as 10-20 A/g.

Two dimension (2D) layered molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has emerged as a promising candidate for the anode material in lithium ion batteries (LIBs). Herein, 2D MoSx (2 ≤ x ≤ 3) nanosheet-coated 1D multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) nanocomposites with hierarchical architecture were synthesized via a high-throughput solvent thermal method under low temperature at 200°C. The unique hierarchical nanostructures with MWNTs backbone and nanosheets of MoSx have significantly promoted the electrode performance in LIBs. Every single MoSx nanosheet interconnect to MWNTs centers with maximized exposed electrochemical active sites, which significantly enhance ion diffusion efficiency and accommodate volume expansion during the electrochemical reaction. A remarkably high specific capacity (i.e., > 1000 mAh/g) was achieved at the current density of 50 mA g(-1), which is much higher than theoretical numbers for either MWNTs or MoS2 along (~372 and ~670 mAh/g, respectively). We anticipate 2D nanosheets/1D MWNTs nanocomposites will be promising materials in new generation practical LIBs.

Effect of Fluoroethylene Carbonate (FEC) on the Performance and Surface Chemistry of Si-Nanowire Li-Ion Battery Anodes
Etacheri, Vinodkumar; Haik, Ortal; Goffer, Yossi; Roberts, Gregory A.; Stefan, Ionel C.; Fasching, Rainier; Aurbach, Doron
Langmuir
(
2012
),
28
(
1
),
965-976
CODEN:
LANGD5
; ISSN:
0743-7463
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
The effect of FEC as a co-solvent on the electrochem. performance and surface chem. of silicon nanowire (SiNW) anodes was thoroughly studied. Enhanced electrochem. performance was obsd. for SiNW anodes in alkyl carbonates electrolyte solns. contg. fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC). Reduced irreversible capacity losses accompanied by enhanced and stable reversible capacities over prolonged cycling were achieved with FEC-contg. electrolyte solns. TEM studies provided evidence for the complete and incomplete lithiation of SiNW's in FEC-contg. and FEC-free electrolyte solns., resp. SEM results proved the formation of much thinner and compact surface films on SiNW's in FEC-contg. solns. However, thicker surface films were identified for SiNW electrodes cycled in FEC-free solns. SiNW electrodes develop lower impedance in electrolyte solns. contg. FEC in contrast to std. (FEC-free) solns. The surface chem. of SiNW electrodes cycled in FEC-modified and std. electrolytes were studied using XPS and FTIR spectroscopy. The impact of FEC as a co-solvent on the electrochem. behavior of SiNW electrodes is discussed herein in light of the spectroscopic and microscopic studies.
